diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. It's predominantly seen in children. The symptoms align with the query: fever, rash, and redness in lips and eyes.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system attacks its own tissues, causing widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs, including skin rash and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often known as mono or the kissing disease, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. It presents with fever, rash, and may include signs of anemia.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from an infection with group A Streptococcus bacteria, causing a distinctive rash, fever, and redness in the face.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A severe reaction to certain medications that includes a rash, fever, eosinophilia, and can affect other organs including the kidneys (hence pyuria).

diagnoses.name: Henoch-Schönlein Purpura
diagnoses.description: An inflammation of the small blood vessels that can cause rash, joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement, potentially leading to the presence of white blood cells in the urine (pyuria).

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes. It's usually a reaction to a medication or an infection. Fever and a painful purplish-red rash are characteristic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection that affects the respiratory system, immune system, and skin, causing a characteristic rash, fever, and Koplik's spots inside the mouth.

diagnoses.name: Toxic Shock Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening complication of certain types of bacterial infections, often associated with tampon use. Symptoms include fever, rash, and multi-organ involvement.

diagnoses.name: Erythema Infectiosum (Fifth Disease)
diagnoses.description: A mild viral infection that most commonly affects children. Symptoms include a 'slapped cheek' rash on the face, fever, and light red rash that can spread to the body.

diagnoses: Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Coxsackievirus Infection (Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)

diagnoses.name: Measles
diagnoses.description: A highly contagious viral infection causing fever, cough, and characteristic spots. Often presents with conjunctivitis, rashes, and sometimes lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Rubella
diagnoses.description: A contagious viral infection best known for its distinctive red rash. It can cause conjunctivitis, a pink rash, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called "mono" or the "kissing disease," this infection is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus and can result in fever, a sore throat, fatigue, swollen lymph nodes (lymphadenopathy), and rashes.

diagnoses.name: Kawasaki Disease
diagnoses.description: A disease that causes inflammation in the walls of some blood vessels in the body. Its symptoms include fever, rash, swelling of the hands and feet, redness in the eyes (conjunctivitis), and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Adenovirus infection
diagnoses.description: A type of viral infection that can influence many parts of the body and can cause a wide range of symptoms, including conjunctivitis, fever, sore throat, and, in some cases, a rash.

diagnoses.name: Scarlet Fever
diagnoses.description: A disease resulting from group A Streptococcus (strep throat) infection, characterized by a distinctive rash, fever, and sore throat. Swollen lymph nodes and red, swollen eyes may also occur.

diagnoses.name: Zika virus
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne virus that may cause conjunctivitis, rash, fever, and joint pain. While often mild, it's notably associated with birth defects if acquired during pregnancy.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A virus transmitted by mosquitoes causing fever, joint pain, and rashes. It may also cause conjunctivitis and swollen glands.

diagnoses.name: Toxoplasmosis
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii, presenting with flu-like symptoms. Rare cases may involve a rash and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Stevens-Johnson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare, serious disorder of the skin and mucous membranes, often reacting to a medication or infection. Symptoms include a painful red or purplish rash that spreads and blisters, conjunctivitis, and facial swelling.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS) syndrome
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can damage any part of the body, including skin, joints, and/or internal organs. Symptoms go through cycles of flare-ups and remissions and can include fever, rash, joint pain, and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium which is spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include fever, headache, fatigue, depression, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. It has several stages, including an initial sore, followed by a rash, and eventually could lead to severe symptoms including difficulties with coordination, paralysis, numbness, blindness, and dementia.

diagnoses.name: Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection transmitted by ticks causing a rash, fever, headache, and muscle pain. It can be severe or deadly if not treated in the first few days.

diagnoses.name: Dengue Fever
diagnoses.description: A mosquito-borne tropical disease caused by the dengue virus. Symptoms often include fever, headache, rash, and muscle and joint pain. Severe cases can result in bleeding, low levels of blood platelets, and blood plasma leakage.

diagnoses.name: Chikungunya
diagnoses.description: A viral disease transmitted to humans by infected mosquitoes. It causes fever and severe joint pain. Other symptoms include muscle pain, headache, nausea, fatigue, and rash.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV) damages the immune system and interferes with the body's ability to fight the organisms that cause disease. AIDS is the most advanced stage of HIV infection.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatic Fever
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can develop as a complication of inadequately treated strep throat or scarlet fever. It can cause permanent damage to the heart, including damaged heart valves and heart failure.

diagnoses.name: Leptospirosis
diagnoses.description: A bacterial infection spread mainly by contact with water or soil contaminated by the urine of infected animals. Symptoms can range from none to severe and can include fever, headache, bleeding, muscle pain, chills, red eyes, and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Psittacosis (Parrot Fever)
diagnoses.description: An infection caused by Chlamydia psittaci, a type of bacteria found in the droppings and nasal discharges of infected birds. Symptoms can include fever, rash, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and cough.

diagnoses: Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia with Thrombocytopenia)
Schizophrenia (in rare cases with severe leukopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can affect the skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs.

diagnoses.name: Viral Infections
diagnoses.description: Various viral infections can lead to symptoms like maculopapular rash, pleural effusion, and in some cases, delirium, especially in severe cases or in immunocompromised individuals.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. In severe cases, it can lead to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis, characterized by joint pain and skin lesions. May also involve systemic manifestations.

diagnoses.name: Drug Reactions
diagnoses.description: Adverse drug reactions can manifest as maculopapular rash, pleural effusion, delirium, and synovitis, depending on the medication and the individual's reaction.

diagnoses.name: Infective Endocarditis
diagnoses.description: An infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and valves. It can present with multiple non-specific symptoms including fever, rash, joint pain, and in severe cases, delirium.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the formation of granulomas in various organs, including the lungs, skin, and lymph nodes, potentially leading to pleural effusion and rash.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and a distinct skin rash. It can also have systemic features including joint pain (synovitis).

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.description: A group of autoimmune diseases causing fibrosis of the skin, joints, blood vessels, and internal organs. It can manifest with joint inflammation, skin changes, and in some cases, pleural effusion.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare inflammatory arthritis characterized by fever, rash, and joint pain. It encompasses Adult-Onset Still's Disease (AOSD) and Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (JIA).

diagnoses: Viral infections (e.g., Dengue fever, HIV, COVID-19)
Infectious Diseases (e.g., Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Parvovirus, HIV)

diagnoses.name: Vitamin A deficiency
reasoning: Follicular hyperkeratosis and dyspigmentation can both be manifestations of this condition due to the role of vitamin A in skin health.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
reasoning: Can lead to delirium, especially in severe cases (myxedema coma), and may also cause changes in the skin texture like hyperkeratosis.

diagnoses.name: Scurvy (Vitamin C deficiency)
reasoning: While not directly causing delirium, severe deficiency can lead to systemic symptoms. Follicular hyperkeratosis is a recognized symptom, and there could be skin changes due to poor wound healing.

diagnoses.name: Kwashiorkor
reasoning: Protein malnutrition that can lead to edema, including pleural effusion, and skin changes, possibly similar to dyspigmentation.

diagnoses.name: Dermatitis herpetiformis
reasoning: While primarily a skin condition with blistering rash and hyperkeratosis, associated conditions like nutritional deficiencies due to celiac disease might indirectly cause some of the other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Hartnup disease
reasoning: A metabolic disorder that can lead to skin changes resembling pellagra and possibly systemic symptoms that could relate to the presented symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Zinc deficiency
reasoning: Can result in skin manifestations including hyperkeratosis. Severe deficiency could also potentially contribute to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
reasoning: Can lead to a wide variety of symptoms including skin changes and systemic effects. Pleural effusion could occur due to opportunistic infections.

diagnoses.name: Nephrotic syndrome
reasoning: Most known for causing edema, including pleural effusion, due to protein loss in the urine. The skin changes could be secondary to the overall condition.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
reasoning: An autoimmune disease that can cause a wide range of symptoms, including skin manifestations (dyspigmentation, hyperkeratosis) and pleural effusion. Central nervous system involvement can lead to psychiatric manifestations like delirium.

diagnoses: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with polyangiitis, Microscopic polyangiitis)
Epilepsy (secondary to CNS involvement in systemic diseases)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE is a chronic autoimmune disease that can affect various organs and tissues of the body. It can lead to symptoms such as atrophic scarring, leukopenia, autoimmune hemolysis, and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease (MCTD)
diagnoses.rationale: MCTD is an autoimmune disorder that has features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including leukopenia, autoimmune hemolysis, and pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting joints, in its systemic form, rheumatoid arthritis can cause leukopenia and has been associated with pericarditis and autoimmune disorders.

diagnoses.name: Scleroderma
diagnoses.rationale: Scleroderma can lead to scarring of skin (atrophic scarring) and internal organs. Autoimmune hemolysis and pericarditis are less common but possible complications.

diagnoses.name: Evans Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Evans Syndrome is a rare autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system produces antibodies that attack its own red and white blood cells (autoimmune hemolysis and leukopenia) and platelets.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Lymphoproliferative Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This condition involves a dysregulation of the immune system, which can lead to autoimmune manifestations such as autoimmune hemolysis and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: While specifically impacting the kidneys, lupus nephritis can occur in individuals with SLE, who also experience the other listed symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can cause blood clots, miscarriages, and is often associated with diseases like SLE. It can indirectly lead to complications such as autoimmune hemolysis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Although primarily known as a viral infection, in some cases, it can lead to autoimmune phenomena like hemolysis and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Hemophagocytic Lymphohistiocytosis
diagnoses.rationale: This rare disorder causes the immune system to attack the body's tissues, potentially leading to symptoms like those listed due to extreme immune dysregulation.

diagnoses: Schizophrenia (in rare cases with concurrent somatic conditions)
Hepatitis B or C with renal involvement
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjögren's syndrome)
Neurological conditions (e.g., epilepsy, cerebral venous sinus thrombosis)
Psychiatric conditions (e.g., bipolar disorder, schizophrenia during acute episodes)
Toxic/metabolic disorders (e.g., acute intoxication, hepatic encephalopathy)
Drug reaction or side effects (e.g., anticholinergic toxicity, Neuroleptic Malignant Syndrome)
Paraneoplastic syndromes (e.g., limbic encephalitis associated with small cell lung cancer)
Cardiac conditions leading to embolic strokes with subsequent seizures (e.g., infective endocarditis)
Pulmonary conditions, including infectious diseases like tuberculosis or pneumonia that may lead to pleural effusion and systemic symptoms
Central nervous system infections (e.g., meningitis, encephalitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Hepatitis B or C associated arthropathy
Cancer (such as lymphoma or lung cancer)

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infections (UTIs)
diagnoses.description: Infections of the bladder or urethra, often caused by bacteria, leading to symptoms such as a strong, persistent urge to urinate, a burning sensation when urinating, and cloudy urine.

diagnoses.name: Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS)
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move the legs, often accompanied by uncomfortable sensations. Symptoms usually occur at rest and can be relieved by movement.

diagnoses.name: Hypersensitivity reactions
diagnoses.description: Immune system reactions to a substance that most people do not react to. These can range from mild responses, like allergies, to severe conditions, like anaphylaxis. Symptoms can affect multiple systems including skin, gastrointestinal tract, and respiratory system.

diagnoses.name: Hearing Loss
diagnoses.description: A partial or total inability to hear. It can be caused by many factors, including genetics, age, exposure to noise, infections, and certain medical conditions.

diagnoses.name: Dysgeusia
diagnoses.description: A distortion of the sense of taste. Individuals may experience a persistent unpleasant taste. This condition can be associated with various factors, including medication side effects, chemotherapy, and certain health conditions.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood sugar levels over a prolonged period. It can cause various symptoms and complications, including an increased risk of UTIs due to glucose in the urine, neuropathy contributing to restless legs syndrome, and potentially impacting hearing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition involving the gradual loss of kidney function. It can lead to a buildup of waste products in the body, which may manifest as various symptoms including changes in taste (dysgeusia), and a higher susceptibility to UTIs.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to a wide range of symptoms including sensory disturbances (potentially affecting taste and hearing), urinary symptoms, and restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A common type of anemia that occurs when the body lacks sufficient iron to produce healthy red blood cells. Symptoms can include fatigue, weakened immune response that might increase susceptibility to infections like UTIs, and restless legs syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that primarily causes dry eyes and dry mouth but can also affect other parts of the body, including the nervous system (potentially contributing to dysgeusia and hearing loss), and the urinary system.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which there is not enough iron in the body, which can cause difficulty concentrating, dysphagia, and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that attacks the glands that provide lubrication to the eyes and mouth, causing irritated eyes, dysphagia, and difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: A lack of vitamin B12 that can lead to anemia, difficulty concentrating, and dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues, and sometimes vulvodynia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition, which might cause difficulty concentrating and can be associated with Sjogren's Syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Plummer-Vinson Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that can cause severe iron deficiency anemia and dysphagia due to esophageal webs.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Hemolytic Anemia
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the body's immune system attacks its own red blood cells, leading to anemia, and can also cause difficulty concentrating.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. It can cause difficulty concentrating, among many other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life. It can cause difficulty concentrating and is sometimes associated with anemia.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing anemia, dysphagia, and could potentially contribute to difficulty concentrating.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially leading to a variety of symptoms, including abnormal electrolytes and decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys do not work effectively. It can cause abnormal electrolytes, decreased libido, and sometimes contributes to tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, but can also include abnormal electrolyte levels, hypersensitivity reactions, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: A chronic, potentially life-threatening condition caused by the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV). It can lead to hypersensitivity reactions, lymphadenitis, and affect the body in multiple ways including decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that occurs when your body's immune system attacks your own tissues and organs, potentially leading to abnormal electrolytes, hypersensitivity reactions, and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. It can feature hypersensitivity reactions and sometimes lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Medication Side Effects
diagnoses.description: Several medications can cause side effects, including abnormal electrolytes, hypersensitivity reactions, tinnitus, and decreased libido.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.description: A sexually transmitted infection that can cause a wide range of symptoms in various stages, including hypersensitivity reactions and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium spread by ticks. It can sometimes cause lymphadenitis and possibly affect hearing (tinnitus).

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disease that causes high blood sugar. Over time, it can affect many bodily systems, leading to abnormal electrolytes and decreased libido.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by persistently depressed mood or loss of interest in activities, causing significant impairment in daily life.

diagnoses.name: Premenstrual Dysphoric Disorder
diagnoses.description: A severe form of premenstrual syndrome (PMS) leading to significant emotional and physical symptoms, including depression, bloating, and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by unreasonable thoughts and fears (obsessions) that lead to compulsive behaviors.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A group of mental health disorders characterized by significant anxiety or fear that is difficult to control, affecting daily activities.

diagnoses.name: Irritable Bowel Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A common disorder affecting the large intestine, causing symptoms like bloating, cramping, abdominal pain, and altered bowel habits.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age, causing irregular menstrual periods, excess hair growth, acne, and obesity.

diagnoses.name: Endometriosis
diagnoses.description: A disorder in which tissue similar to the tissue that normally lines the inside of your uterus grows outside your uterus, causing pain and potentially leading to fertility problems.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms such as fatigue, depression, and weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Allergy
diagnoses.description: An allergic hypersensitivity reaction to various substances, potentially leading to symptoms such as swelling, rash, itching, and difficulty breathing.

diagnoses: Eating disorders (e.g., anorexia nervosa, bulimia nervosa)

diagnoses.explanation: Certain autoimmune disorders can present a combination of symptoms, such as ulcers (mouth or gastrointestinal) and episodic weakness, which could be related to conditions like lupus or Sjögren's syndrome.
A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout the body, which can lead to ulcers and other symptoms mentioned.
Conditions such as Crohn's disease or ulcerative colitis could explain the ulcers and may indirectly lead to conditions like pneumonia due to overall health compromise.
This is a direct match for one of the symptoms, which involves tissue similar to the lining inside the uterus growing outside it, potentially affecting general health.
Weak immune systems can lead to frequent infections such as pneumonia and also affect the body's ability to heal, potentially worsening or complicating conditions like ulcers and leukoplakia.
Certain types of cancers can present with leukoplakia (especially oral cancers), ulcers, and cause systemic symptoms like episodic weakness.

Some neurological disorders could potentially lead to episodic weakness and may also indirectly affect other systemic conditions, exacerbating symptoms like ulcers or predisposing to infections like pneumonia.
This could lead to multiple infections (such as pneumonia) and impact the body's ability to manage other symptoms like ulcers.
Deficiencies, particularly B vitamins and iron, could potentially cause or exacerbate leukoplakia and ulcers, and overall weakness.

Inflammation of blood vessels, which can reduce blood flow to organs and tissues, possibly explaining ulcers, episodic weakness, and contributing to the development of pneumonia due to overall compromised health.

diagnoses.description: Premenstrual syndrome (PMS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Overlap between anxiety and dysmenorrhea which fits the pattern of premenstrual syndrome.

diagnoses.description: Anxiety disorder
diagnoses.reasoning: Direct match for the anxiety symptom, and anxiety can sometimes manifest or exacerbate other physical symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Autoimmune disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause a wide spectrum of symptoms, including lymphadenopathy, angioedema, and indirectly dysmenorrhea due to systemic inflammation.

diagnoses.description: Hormonal imbalances
diagnoses.reasoning: Direct link to dysmenorrhea and possible indirect association with anxiety and lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.description: Infectious mononucleosis
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause lymphadenopathy, potential for throat inflammation leading to laryngitis, and might induce dysmenorrhea as a symptom of systemic illness.

diagnoses.description: Allergic reactions
diagnoses.reasoning: Direct link to angioedema; certain allergic reactions might also cause lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.description: Thyroid disorders
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause menstrual irregularities (including dysmenorrhea), anxiety, and potentially contribute to lymphadenopathy through autoimmune processes.

diagnoses.description: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reasoning: Though it wouldn’t directly cause angioedema or laryngitis, fibromyalgia could theoretically worsen experiences of pain related to dysmenorrhea and is associated with anxiety.

diagnoses.description: Chronic fatigue syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: May exacerbate or be associated with symptoms such as lymphadenopathy and anxiety, but less directly associated with the other listed symptoms.

diagnoses.description: Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reasoning: Directly relates to dysmenorrhea; can indirectly lead to anxiety through hormonal imbalances.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.description: Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID)
Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
Hepatitis (various forms including A, B, C, autoimmune)
Primary biliary cholangitis
Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
Anxiety disorder
Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)
HIV/AIDS
Lyme disease
Sjögren's syndrome

diagnoses: Occupational asthma due to chemical exposure

diagnoses.name: Upper respiratory infection
diagnoses.description: An infection of the upper respiratory tract, which may cause symptoms similar to those listed, including congestion.

diagnoses.name: Acute otitis externa
diagnoses.description: Also known as swimmer's ear, it's an inflammation of the ear canal, which fits the otitis externa symptom.

diagnoses.name: Pneumonia
diagnoses.description: An infection that inflames the air sacs in one or both lungs, which can be aligned with symptoms like obstructive sleep apnea due to difficulty breathing.

diagnoses.name: Obstructive Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by repeated stops and starts in breathing during sleep, which may be exacerbated by conditions like upper respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Allergic rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms. Can also lead to congestion.

diagnoses.name: Chronic sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinuses that can cause congestion, impacting sleep and potentially leading to secondary infections like otitis externa.

diagnoses.name: Lymphadenopathy
diagnoses.description: Disease of the lymph nodes, which could be secondary to infections such as pneumonia or viral upper respiratory infections.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system — nose, throat and lungs. Influenza is commonly called the flu, but it's not the same as stomach 'flu' viruses that cause diarrhea and vomiting.

diagnoses.name: Tonsillitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the tonsils, which can cause obstructive symptoms affecting sleep, difficulty swallowing, and might coexist with lymphadenopathy.

diagnoses.name: Asthma
diagnoses.description: Asthma can cause severe respiratory symptoms, including difficulty breathing, which could be mistaken or contribute to sleep apnea symptoms. It may also exacerbate conditions like pneumonia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by inflammation of the sinuses lasting more than 12 weeks despite medical treatment.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Common Variable Immune Deficiency (CVID)
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by a low level of antibodies, leading to increased susceptibility to infection.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Apnea
diagnoses.description: A sleep disorder in which breathing repeatedly stops and starts, can lead to insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Also known as high blood pressure, can sometimes cause lability in blood pressure readings.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.description: A rare tumor of adrenal gland tissue that causes an overproduction of hormones leading to high blood pressure, headaches, and sweating.

diagnoses.name: Primary Immunodeficiency Diseases
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by a poor immune response and increased susceptibility to infections.

diagnoses.name: Vasomotor Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: Non-allergic rhinitis that causes chronic sneezing, congestion, or runny nose.

diagnoses.name: Nasal Polyps
diagnoses.description: Soft, painless, noncancerous growths on the lining of your nasal passages or sinuses that may block nasal passages.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: An anxiety disorder characterized by chronic anxiety, exaggerated worry and tension, even when there is little or nothing to provoke it, can lead to insomnia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Stress
diagnoses.description: Long-term stress can lead to a variety of symptoms, including anxiety and potential impacts on the immune system, possibly influencing the production of immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: Generalized anxiety disorder and other anxiety-related conditions could account for the anxiety and may indirectly affect other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that leads to an increased number of red blood cells. This condition might also contribute to symptoms such as tinnitus and is directly associated with polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases like Sjogren's Syndrome can cause dry eyes and mouth, potentially leading to tinnitus, and may also lead to lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Hyperimmune Conditions
diagnoses.description: Conditions leading to an overactive immune response, potentially increasing immunoglobulin levels.

diagnoses.name: Infections
diagnoses.description: Chronic or acute infections can lead to lymphadenitis, affect immunoglobulin levels, and potentially cause anxiety and tinnitus through systemic illness effects.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest. It may involve immune system abnormalities.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: Cancer of the lymphatic system, which can cause lymphadenitis and potentially affect immunoglobulin levels due to immune system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as Graves' disease or Hashimoto's thyroiditis can lead to anxiety, affect immune function, and may indirectly impact symptoms like tinnitus.

diagnoses.name: Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Also known as mono, caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, can cause lymphadenitis, increase certain classes of immunoglobulins, and lead to fatigue and potential anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Immune Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.description: A disorder that can lead to easy or excessive bruising and bleeding. The bleeding results from unusually low levels of platelets — the cells that help blood clot.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Myeloid Leukemia
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow. Monocytosis can be a symptom of this disease, alongside anemia, which indirectly can cause symptoms like difficulty focusing due to fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. It can lead to a wide range of symptoms, including migratory abdominal pain, difficulty focusing (due to CNS involvement), and potentially blood disorders like thrombocytopenia which might cause epistaxis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder causing blood vessel inflammation throughout your body. Symptoms can include mouth sores, genital sores, inflammation inside the eye, and skin problems like warts.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immunodeficiency syndrome can manifest with a wide variety of symptoms including warts (due to human papillomavirus), weight loss, fever, and monocytosis as the body fights the infection.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough hormones. Symptoms can include fatigue, which might lead to difficulty focusing, and possibly migratory abdominal pain.

diagnoses.name: Psoriasis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune condition that can cause skin cells to grow too quickly, resulting in thick, white, silvery, or red patches of skin. In some cases, psoriasis can be associated with other systemic symptoms, including joint pain and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease in which the immune system eats away at the protective covering of nerves. Symptoms can include difficulty with coordination and balance, difficulty focusing (due to optic neuritis), and fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Symptoms can include fatigue, weight loss, and skin manifestations such as rashes or warts.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: This deficiency can lead to anemia, causing fatigue and weakness. Advanced deficiency might cause damage to the optic nerve or spinal cord, resulting in vision difficulties and neurological symptoms.

diagnoses: Thyroid Disorders (such as Hypothyroidism or Hyperthyroidism)
Viral Infections (e.g., Epstein-Barr virus, leading to infectious mononucleosis)
Allergic reactions (e.g., hay fever, allergic conjunctivitis)

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.description: A type of blood cancer that causes the bone marrow to make too many red blood cells, leading to polycythemia. This can result in increased blood viscosity, potentially contributing to symptoms such as fatigue and potentially impacting healing processes.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder characterized by persistent feelings of sadness, hopelessness, and a lack of energy or fatigue. Mood lability and pseudo-seizures can also be presentations in severe cases.

diagnoses.name: Bipolar Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health condition that causes extreme mood swings including emotional highs (mania or hypomania) and lows (depression), which can reflect as mood lability. Fatigue can also occur.

diagnoses.name: Conversion Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental condition in which a person has blindness, paralysis, or other nervous system symptoms that cannot be explained by medical evaluation, including pseudoseizures.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. Though not directly associated with polycythemia, individuals may report poor healing.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Myeloproliferative Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases of the bone marrow and blood that cause an increase in the production of blood cells. These can be related to polycythemia and may also result in symptoms such as fatigue.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Anemia caused by a shortage of iron in the body, leading to fewer red blood cells. This condition can result in fatigue, but it is typically associated with decreased hemoglobin levels rather than polycythemia.

diagnoses.name: Sleep Disorders
diagnoses.description: Conditions that affect the ability to sleep well on a regular basis, which can result in fatigue, mood changes, and potentially affect healing processes.

diagnoses.name: Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD)
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by failure to recover after experiencing or witnessing a terrifying event. Symptoms may include pseudo-seizures, mood lability, and fatigue.

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests

diagnoses.name: Primary Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: This condition can explain dyspnea, osteopenia (due to calcium metabolism disorder), and possibly contribute to hypertension. However, direct causation of epistaxis or word-finding difficulty is less evident, suggesting these may be associated with hypertension or other systemic effects.

diagnoses.name: Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
diagnoses.rationale: A rare condition that can cause systemic symptoms including epistaxis due to nasal granulomas, dyspnea (even with normal pulmonary function tests due to upper airway involvement), and possibly affect cognition or blood pressure indirectly. However, direct association with osteopenia or word-finding difficulty needs careful differential diagnosis.

diagnoses.name: Hypertensive Emergency
diagnoses.rationale: Severely elevated blood pressure could lead to end-organ damage with symptoms of blood pressure lability, possibly dyspnea (from acute heart failure or pulmonary edema), and neurological symptoms including word-finding difficulty. Epistaxis is a common presenting symptom of acute hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Excess cortisol production can lead to osteopenia (due to increased bone resorption), hypertension (blood pressure lability), and symptoms like dyspnea due to muscle weakness. Epistaxis is not a primary symptom but could be related to secondary effects like hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Pheochromocytoma
diagnoses.rationale: This tumor secretes catecholamines episodically, leading to episodes of hypertension (blood pressure lability), possibly contributing to episodes of dyspnea, headache, and perhaps indirectly to epistaxis due to high blood pressure. It does not directly cause osteopenia or word-finding difficulty but could contribute to systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Renal Artery Stenosis
diagnoses.rationale: This condition leads to secondary hypertension, which could explain blood pressure lability and possibly contribute to symptoms like dyspnea due to heart failure. The relationship with osteopenia, epistaxis, and word-finding difficulty is less direct but could arise from complications of uncontrolled hypertension.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: A group of disorders causing inflammation of blood vessels, which could explain the dyspnea (via lung involvement), high blood pressure lability, and epistaxis (due to nasal vessel involvement). Cognitive symptoms could arise from cerebral vasculitis. Osteopenia may be secondary to long-term inflammation or steroid use.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: A systemic autoimmune disease that could potentially explain osteopenia (through chronic inflammation or corticosteroid treatment), hypertension (renal involvement), episodic dyspnea (pleuritis or pulmonary hypertension), and potentially neurological symptoms including word-finding difficulty. Epistaxis could be related to mucosal involvement.

diagnoses.name: Hyperthyroidism
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause osteopenia (due to increased bone turnover), dyspnea (due to increased metabolic demands and possibly cardiopulmonary involvement), and hypertension. However, the direct association with epistaxis or word-finding difficulty might be less common but can be involved in systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Neurofibromatosis Type 1
diagnoses.rationale: A genetic disorder that can manifest with a wide range of symptoms, including hypertension (due to pheochromocytoma or renal artery stenosis), cognitive symptoms (including word-finding difficulty due to neurofibromas in the brain), and bone abnormalities like osteopenia. Epistaxis and dyspnea might be less directly associated but could be part of the broader symptomatology.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin C Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to easy bleeding and other symptoms due to its role in collagen synthesis and blood vessel health.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: Hepatitis C can cause liver fibrosis and dyslipidemia. It may also indirectly lead to other symptoms through its impact on the liver.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: Diabetes can lead to dyslipidemia and may cause complications such as diabetic retinopathy, which can impair vision.

diagnoses.name: Dyskeratosis Congenita
diagnoses.description: This genetic disorder can cause leukoplakia, fibrosis of various tissues, and other systemic issues.

diagnoses.name: Iron Deficiency Anemia
diagnoses.description: Iron deficiency can cause easy bleeding and may contribute to difficulty focusing vision due to its effect on hemoglobin and oxygen transport.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: HIV/AIDS can lead to leukoplakia and dyslipidemia, among many other symptoms, as a result of its impact on the immune system.

diagnoses.name: Von Willebrand Disease
diagnoses.description: This inherited bleeding disorder can explain easy bleeding due to defects in clotting factor proteins.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: Chronic kidney disease can lead to dyslipidemia and a buildup of waste products, which can cause a variety of symptoms including issues with vision.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Hypothyroidism can contribute to dyslipidemia and may indirectly cause or worsen symptoms like difficulty focusing vision.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disease can cause dry eyes, leading to difficulty focusing vision, and may also associate with dyslipidemia and leukoplakia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It can affect anyone, but it's more common in people who are black or of south Asian origin.

diagnoses.name: Secondary Hypertension
diagnoses.description: High blood pressure that's caused by another medical condition, such as chronic kidney disease, which can also lead to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder characterized by high blood glucose levels. Over time, it can damage the kidneys (diabetic nephropathy), contribute to mood lability, and cause xerosis.

diagnoses.name: Uremia
diagnoses.description: A condition involving abnormally high levels of waste products in the blood, typically due to chronic kidney disease, which can also contribute to mood lability and irritations leading to physical sensitivities.

diagnoses.name: Endocrine Disorders
diagnoses.description: Disorders such as hyperthyroidism or hypothyroidism can cause mood lability, blood pressure lability, and contribute to the worsening of chronic kidney disease.

diagnoses.name: Renal Osteodystrophy
diagnoses.description: A bone disorder that occurs when the kidneys fail to maintain the proper levels of calcium and phosphorus in the blood, associated with chronic kidney disease. It can contribute to physical sensitivities due to bone pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A condition where the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should, which can be worsened by or contribute to chronic kidney disease. It can also cause fluid retention leading to blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Anemia of Chronic Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that commonly occurs with chronic conditions, such as chronic kidney disease, which can contribute to mood lability and general physical deterioration.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mental health condition that can be both a symptom and a cause of physical health issues, such as chronic kidney disease, affecting mood regulation.

diagnoses.name: Electrolyte Imbalances
diagnoses.description: Conditions such as hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia that can occur in chronic kidney disease and contribute to physical sensitivities, mood lability, and blood pressure lability.

diagnoses.name: Type 2 Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reason: Hyperglycemia is a common symptom. Depression and mood lability can be comorbid conditions.

diagnoses.name: Major Depressive Disorder
diagnoses.reason: Depression as a primary condition can be associated with mood lability and can indirectly affect physical health.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.reason: Can present with depression, mood lability, and is associated with insulin resistance which can lead to hyperglycemia.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reason: Can lead to osteopenia due to mineral and bone disorder. Depression is also common in CKD.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Disease
diagnoses.reason: May present with symptoms of hyperglycemia, mood lability, and depression due to cortisol excess.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can cause osteopenia and mood lability due to elevated calcium levels.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.reason: Can present with depression and hyperglycemia. Mood lability is less common but can occur.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders (e.g., Lupus)
diagnoses.reason: These can have systemic effects leading to depression, osteopenia, and symptoms similar to interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.reason: Associated with mood lability and depression. Chronic pain syndrome can contribute to a presentation similar to interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Osteoporosis
diagnoses.reason: Advanced form of osteopenia. Depression and mood swings can be related to chronic pain and disability.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn’s Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's Disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Gastrointestinal disorders with autonomic involvement (e.g., IBS)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease or Ulcerative colitis)
Drug reactions (e.g., ACE inhibitors induced angioedema)

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergy-related condition where irritants, typically environmental, cause nasal congestion, rhinorrhea, and sometimes itchy eyes.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can cause a range of symptoms due to high blood sugar levels, including polyuria which can contribute to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system that can cause increased frequency and urgency of urination, potentially leading to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormones, can cause hypotension along with other systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from excessive loss of body water. Severe cases can cause hypotension and may contribute to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Atopic Dermatitis
diagnoses.description: A type of inflammation of the skin (dermatitis) that results in itchy, red, swollen, and cracked skin. Pruritus is a primary symptom.

diagnoses.name: Non-Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: A medical condition involving chronic sneezing or having a congested, drippy nose with no apparent cause, such as allergies.

diagnoses.name: Heart Failure
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition in which the heart doesn't pump blood as well as it should, can lead to hypotension and renal issues, potentially causing incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition characterized by a gradual loss of kidney function over time. It can lead to symptoms like incontinence and hypotension.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition marked by a deficiency of red blood cells or hemoglobin in the blood, leading to fatigue, weakness, and possibly hypotension.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Anaphylaxis (in rare severe cases of angioedema)
Neurodegenerative diseases (such as Parkinson's disease or Progressive Supranuclear Palsy)

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, causing a range of neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (such as scintillation) and other neurological symptoms prior to the headache.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, paralysis, and difficulty speaking or swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Symptoms can depend on the tumor's location but may include headache, seizures, and cognitive or motor impairments.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can lead to difficulties swallowing and speaking.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA is a temporary period of symptoms similar to those of a stroke. It can include headache, paralysis, and speech difficulties but usually resolves within 24 hours.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves. Weakness and tingling in the extremities are usually the first symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Arnold-Chiari Malformation
diagnoses.description: A condition in which brain tissue extends into the spinal canal. It can lead to symptoms such as headache, difficulties swallowing (dysphagia), and motor coordination problems.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, spread by ticks. Early symptoms may include headache, paralysis, and memory problems.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from reduced blood flow to the back part of the brain, which can cause symptoms like dizziness, dysphagia, ataxia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by recurrent attacks of moderate to severe pain. The aura may include visual disturbances such as scotoma, and sometimes speech disturbances (aphasia), with symptoms like weakness occurring usually before the headache itself.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition where poor blood flow to the brain results in cell death. Symptoms can include headache, difficulty speaking (aphasia), visual problems like scotoma, and weakness or paralysis, particularly on one side of the body.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, including headache, aphasia, weakness, and visual disturbances like scotoma, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge in a blood vessel in the brain that can leak or rupture, causing a severe headache, visual disturbances (including scotoma), speech impairments like aphasia, and weakness. It's a medical emergency.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A disease of the brain and spinal cord where the immune system attacks the protective myelin sheath of nerves. Symptoms can vary widely but can include headache, weakness, aphasia, and visual disturbances such as scotoma.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in the brain. Depending on its location, it can cause headaches, visual problems like scotoma, weakness, and aphasia among other symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Encephalitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain, often due to infection. Symptoms can include headache, visual disturbances such as scotoma, weakness, and aphasia. It can be life-threatening and requires medical attention.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, typically caused by an infection. Symptoms can include severe headache, aphasia, weakness, and in severe cases, disturbances in vision.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Headache, aphasia, and weakness can occur post-seizure.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhagic Stroke
diagnoses.description: Caused by a bleed within the brain, which can lead to symptoms such as intense headache, scotoma, weakness, and aphasia. Immediate medical intervention is critical.

diagnoses: Autoimmune Diseases (e.g., Sjogren's syndrome, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus)

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A stroke occurs when the blood supply to part of your brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Brain cells begin to die in minutes. A stroke is a medical emergency, and prompt treatment is crucial.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: Multiple sclerosis (MS) is a potentially disabling disease of the brain and spinal cord (central nervous system). The immune system attacks the protective sheath (myelin) that covers nerve fibers, causing communication problems between your brain and the rest of your body.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A brain tumor is a mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Some brain tumors are noncancerous (benign), and some brain tumors are cancerous (malignant). Brain tumors can begin in your brain (primary brain tumors), or cancer can begin in other parts of your body and spread to your brain (secondary, or metastatic, brain tumors).

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: Migraine is a neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It's frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms may include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound. Migraines can begin in childhood or may not occur until early adulthood.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a brief, temporary disruption of blood supply to your brain. TIAs are often a warning sign of a future stroke and should not be ignored.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Meningitis is an inflammation of the fluid and membranes (meninges) surrounding your brain and spinal cord. The swelling from meningitis typically triggers symptoms such as headache, fever and a stiff neck.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A brain abscess is a collection of pus, immune cells, and other material in the brain, usually from a bacterial or fungal infection. Brain abscesses can cause symptoms including headache, fever, weakness, and speech problems.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: Myasthenia gravis is a chronic autoimmune, neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which are responsible for breathing and moving parts of the body, including the arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Lyme disease is caused by four main species of bacteria. Lyme disease is transmitted by the bite of an infected black-legged tick, commonly known as a deer tick. Symptoms include fever, headache, fatigue, and a characteristic skin rash called erythema migrans. If left untreated, infection can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache that is often accompanied by visual disturbances and other sensory symptoms such as dysarthria, paresthesia, and phonophobia.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, it can cause symptoms similar to a stroke, such as dysarthria and paresthesia, but the symptoms are temporary.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A disease of the central nervous system that can lead to symptoms such as paresthesia, dysarthria, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Depending on its location, a brain tumor can cause a wide range of neurological symptoms, including headache, paresthesia, and changes in speech (dysarthria).

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A condition caused by sudden interruption of blood supply to part of the brain, leading to symptoms such as paresthesia and dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the brain and spinal cord membranes, often causing headache, phonophobia due to increased sensitivity to sounds, and sometimes, dysarthria.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: An infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria. If it affects the nervous system, it can cause symptoms like paresthesia, dysarthria, and headaches.

diagnoses.name: Cerebral Aneurysm
diagnoses.description: A bulge in a blood vessel in the brain that can cause headache, along with symptoms like paresthesia and dysarthria if it presses on brain structures.

diagnoses.name: Epilepsy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder marked by sudden recurrent episodes of sensory disturbance. In some cases, before a seizure, individuals may experience paresthesia, phonophobia, and headache.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to symptoms such as paresthesia and, in severe cases, dysarthria.

diagnoses: Toxic and Metabolic Disorders (e.g., Vitamin B12 Deficiency)
Hepatitis B or C associated cryoglobulinemia
HELLP Syndrome (Hemolysis, Elevated Liver enzymes, Low Platelet count)
Inflammatory bowel disease (Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS) Syndrome
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to Autoimmune Disease
Postinflammatory Hyperpigmentation due to Autoimmune Disorder
Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD) related to autoimmune disease
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS)
Viral infections (e.g., Dengue fever, Zika virus)
Viral infections (e.g., Parvovirus B19, Hepatitis C)
Vasculitis, such as Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis
Viral Infections (such as Epstein-Barr Virus or Cytomegalovirus)
Epilepsy (due to underlying neurological involvement in systemic diseases)
Infectious diseases (e.g., HIV, Hepatitis C) associated with cryoglobulinemia

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that can affect many parts of the body including skin, joints, kidneys, brain, and other organs, causing a wide range of symptoms including rash, arthritis, and kidney problems. The combination of lichen planus, nonscarring alopecia, proteinuria, and hemolytic anemia is consistent with cutaneous manifestations of lupus.

diagnoses.name: Lichen Planopilaris
diagnoses.description: A form of lichen planus affecting the scalp leading to hair loss, which is usually nonscarring. This condition might be considered separately but often occurs in the context of broader systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease marked by muscle weakness and skin rashes. It can also involve other organs, leading to symptoms like proteinuria due to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.description: A disease that may have features of lupus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including muscle weakness, rheumatoid arthritis, and various skin conditions such as lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Hepatitis C
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that leads to liver inflammation, sometimes associated with extrahepatic manifestations including lichen planus, cryoglobulinemia, which can cause symptoms like vasculitis leading to symptoms such as proteinuria and nonscarring alopecia.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that slowly destroys the bile ducts in the liver and can have extrahepatic manifestations including lichen planus.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that affects multiple organs in the body, but mostly the lungs and lymph glands. Skin manifestations like lichen planus and systemic symptoms such as anemia can occur.

diagnoses.name: Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura
diagnoses.description: A rare blood disorder characterized by blood clots in small vessels, which could cause hemolytic anemia and could indirectly be associated with symptoms like nonscarring alopecia due to the systemic nature of the disease.

diagnoses.name: Paroxysmal Nocturnal Hemoglobinuria
diagnoses.description: A rare, life-threatening disease of the blood characterized by destruction of red blood cells, blood clots, and impaired bone marrow function, which may incidentally relate to conditions like proteinuria and anemia.

diagnoses.name: Graft vs Host Disease
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when donor bone marrow or stem cells attack the recipient. It can manifest with various symptoms including lichen planus-like skin changes, alopecia, and can have renal manifestations leading to proteinuria.

diagnoses: Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
Drug reaction with eosinophilia and systemic symptoms (DRESS syndrome)
